Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cervical Epidural Analgesia in Head and Neck Cancer Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: 30 patients aged 18-65 years with ASA status I or II scheduled for elective head and neck cancer surgery were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: 30 patients aged 18-65 years with ASA status I or II scheduled for elective head and neck cancer surgery

Intervention.evidence: Group E (cervical epidural analgesia with general anesthesia) and Group G (general anesthesia alone)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to assess the impact of cervical epidural analgesia on opioid and anesthetic requirements and stress response in patients undergoing head and neck cancer surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was intra-operative morphine, isoflurane, and vecuronium requirements.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sequentially numbered opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the intervention's nature, blinding was not feasible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 30 patients aged 18-65 years with ASA status I or II scheduled for elective head and neck cancer surgery were randomised into two groups

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 30 patients, 15 were randomised to each group, with 14 in Group E and 15 in Group G completing the study.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Group E demonstrated a significant reduction in morphine (p < 0.001), isoflurane (p = 0.004), and vecuronium (p = 0.001) requirements.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events in Group E included bradycardia in 6.6% and hypotension in 13.3% of patients, both manageable with standard interventions.

Funding.evidence: The study reported no financial support.
